newsitem.title: GERMANY: German coffee roasters seen covered until March.
newsitem.headline: German coffee roasters seen covered until March.

text.p: German coffee roasters were mostly covered until the end of the first quarter of 1997 and therefore inactive in outright markets, traders said on Monday.
Only higher than expected seasonal coffee sales at Christmas could create fresh gaps in raw materials cover.
"Weakness on London robustas may drag arabicas down as well but consumers are sidelined," one trader said ahead of the New York reopening after a long holiday weekend.
"It's quite possible that sell-stops will be hit and funds will start selling."
London robustas stayed in range amid profit-taking after hitting 31-month lows last Friday as charts looked weak and key support levels broke.
Physical market interest here focused on Central Americans and East Africans for the second quarter while exporters sought to place more nearby supplies.

Roasters believed the second half of the 1996/97 season would be comfortable because new crops would have been put into stores by then and Colombia might need to sell national stocks to secure revenue for infrastructure measures.
Outright arabica sellers' prices were steady or up to $3 per 50 kgs fob down on the week.
Colombia excelso was $134 and Brazils at $107.50 while Indonesian robustas eased $2.50 to $61 for Dec/Jan cif shipment. --Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
